title: Lorenzo de Arrau
text:
Lorenzo de Arrau (1735–1781) was a Spanish military engineer who served in <a href="Chile">Chile</a> during the second half of the 18th century. 
Biography.
Arrau () was born in <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> in 1735. 
He was sent to the <a href="Captaincy%20General%20of%20Chile">Spanish colony of Chile</a> by King <a href="Charles%20III%20of%20Spain">Carlos III</a> to work as a military engineer. 
De Arrau arrived in Chile in 1763, accompanying Juan Garland and <a href="Ambrosio%20O%27Higgins%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Osorno">Ambrosio O'Higgins</a> (future Marquis of Osorno and Viceroy of Perú and father of <a href="Bernardo%20O%27Higgins">Bernardo O'Higgins</a>, the father of the Chilean independence). He served in <a href="Valdivia">Valdivia</a> in 1764, and in <a href="Santiago">Santiago</a> where he established an <a href="arsenal">arsenal</a> for the manufacture of <a href="cannon">cannon</a>s. 
He married Isabel de Santa María Escobedo y Baeza, and they had six children: Juan (single), Pedro Juan (a down-to-earth rancher and an ancestor of pianist <a href="Claudio%20Arrau">Claudio Arrau</a>), Clara, Juana, Cruz, and Manuela Bárbara (nun).
He died in 1781 in <a href="Chill%C3%A1n">Chillán</a>, Chile. 
His son Pedro Juan de Arrau y Santa Maria married Carmen Darroch del Solar, a descendant of Reverend John Darroch (who descended from the Campbells of Craignish, Scotland) and his wife Elspeth Campbell (of the Campbells of Glenorchy, Scotland).
Lorenzo de Arrau y Alguer-Suari belonged to a family of painters and artists from Barcelona famous since the 17th century. The origins of the Arraus can be found in <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> and, further, in <a href="France">France</a>. One of his descendants is the Chilean pianist <a href="Claudio%20Arrau">Claudio Arrau</a>.
